history.content:
Definitely think you should take 170 given the importance you've placed on recruiting. Not only are a large proportion of relevant interview questions directly related to the algorithms taught in 170, but the type of thinking you develop in 170 helps a lot when presented with different/difficult interview questions. Of course, you could always learn all the algorithms on your own, but I found that learning them in the environment of 170 made actual interview questions feel a lot easier.

Example off the top of my head: In one of my 170 discussion section worksheets there was a question that asked about wanting to be able to pick a spot on a mountain where your view is not blocked by any surrounding area. An interview question I received asked about finding a local maximum in a 2d array. As you can see the discussion worksheet question was the same as the interview question but asked in a much less direct way. I've found that this has been the case for most interview questions I've received.

tl;dr do 170 for recruiting

children.subject: Yup. As long as you can ~actually focus~ during webcasts then you shouldn't have to go to live lecture. I ended up webcasting halfway through the semester since I found myself going back and rewatching parts that I wanted to review anyway.

How important is it to watch 170 lectures live, if at all? Is it easier to absorb information in person? From a webcast? Or just notes and hw?

For reference, I took CS70 last semester and attended lecture maybe 3 or 4 times, but still got an A by keeping up with the notes and homework. Is a similar approach feasible for an A in 170?

history.content:
In general, 170 and 126 are both viewed as core courses that are entry-level upper-div courses. 120 is also an entry-level upper-div course, but does not quite have the same universal core-level status that 126 or 170 do.

For ML, the two main core upper-div courses are 126 and 127, both are entry-level upper-divs. For SP more broadly, 120 would be added to that list. 

All of this suggests that if you really want to take two EECS upper divs per term, those two should be 126 and 170 in the Fall, with 127 and 120 in the Spring. 

In general, having two lectures at the same time is a pretty strong signal that you should not take both of them simultaneously.

I'm a rising junior and I'm looking into focusing on Signals and ML. My current plan for Fall 18 is to take EE 120, EECS 126, and Phys 7A. I also plan to focus on recruiting in order to secure an internship at a big name company (e.g. Google, Amazon, etc.).

However, CS 170 appears critical for recruiting season as it teaches fundamentals in algorithms. CS 170 and EE 120 have a time conflict this semester (but they allow dual enrollment and EE 120 does not have a final). Considering this, would it be wise to replace EECS 126 with CS 170? I could take EECS 126 in Spring, which is when I originally planned to take CS 170.
history.subject: CS 170 or EE 126.
